column328: Please explain, add your thoughts, provide suggestions for changes for the above section:

column7: In my opinion, too much focus on theory and basically no focus at all on applied research. As an applied person, I would have appreciated learning more useful things, e.g. how to derive an estimator (which, except for GMM, we didn't)
column9: Especially in the first term, the workload was very heavy and kind of suffocating. The second term was much better to that regard, but I think the program would benefit a lot from more carefully allocating time and resources between the three main courses. The first semester, we did not do anything at all in Metrics, which turned out to be good since Micro and Macro were incredibly intense. But cutting some topics in Macro and making sure we have a good basis in Stats seems more important to me.
column11: It was good to have time during the math camp to get to know each other. Maybe during the beginning, there could be one or two more department events, like a common dinner etc to facilitate getting to know each other.
column13: Especially during the first term, some people got very competitive which was not very beneficial and counterproductive for studying. I think this could be mediated by emphasizing group work aspects more.
column15: In the first semester, there weren't any study groups that would meet regularily to solve Psets etc, which made it hard to catch up with the material. I think the department needs to do more to encourage group work. One thing that worked well with that regard was that in Micro, we had to submit Psets in the group before the TA session and during the TA session, people were selected at random to present an exercise. This really helped to form groups and work with our peers.
column19: Group work didn't work out really well, esp. not in the beginning. In general, my feeling is that we had some students for whom most things were quite easy and so they did not participate much and weren't present at the office often. It'd be good to find a better way for people to benefit from each other's knowledge. For us, people who knew the material mainly just withdrew and did other things, while the rest was trying to catch up.
column21: Especially in the first term, there was no focus (nor material) in metrics. Micro I was good in terms of workload and topics covered, but I would have preferred a slimmer schedule for Macro and instead learn more things in Metrics I. In my opinion, it might be beneficial to move Winkelmanns part from Metrics II into the first semester (to make sure we learn at least something), and focus the entire second semester on the topics Pietro covered and learn how to derive things (instead of just scratching on the surface of all the different estimation methods). The second semester, the workload between the courses was much more equally distributed.
column23: Maybe in general, having classes more in blocks (e.g. 8-12) works better to have time in the afternoon and evening to study. We often had 10-12 and then 2-4, which kind of ruined the whole day.
column25: Would be preferable to have midterms, as a feedback loop and also in terms of getting to know what professors expect.

column3: I changed my understanding of economics in some sub-fields, such as political economics, auctions and so on.
column11: I really like my cohorts!!! (though I seldom stayed in the office...) They are so kind and so interesting!!! Veda really helps me a lot since I meet her most often in the office.
column13: I think the atmosphere is cooperative but not competitive.
column15: It is my own problem. I think my cohorts often form a study group and do well.
column17: I would try to work harder and discuss with others in the second year.
column21: I spent most time on Macro and spent little time in Metrics
column23: I learnt most from Macro TA sessions.
column25: I think it is OK. Maybe three terms works better for the second year? Lets see in the second year.
column27: I think my computing training is poor. Maybe its my own problem.
column33: I had no touch with the junior mentor...
column58: I felt it very difficult to catch up at the beginning. For me it would be better if the class can be slower at the beginning.
column148: Since this is Damian's first year...maybe we can be optimistic next year.

column7:
This is a general comments related to previous three questions. It would be extremely efficient if the exemption of courses can be warranted on an individual basis, possibly even without means of examination. I would argue both current situation (1) where taking all three courses is mandatory and the situation (2) where exemption is based on passing entry-exam would incur welfare loss.

To illustrate, suppose a person likes macro so much, wants to do research on macro, and performs A+ in macro in the previous degree which covers most of the first year material in macro here (suppose he is not so fascinated with / good at micro): what is the welfare consequence of him (1) to take all three courses again? or (2) to exempt some courses based on an entry examination?

(Case 1: the current situation) he again performs well in macro because he likes it so much. However, the marginal gain is quite limited since he knew most of the material. Meanwhile, the opportunity cost of attending lectures, handing in problem sets, preparing for exams is high enough to occupy most of his working time. On the other hand, he could learn a lot from the courses, but most likely from micro, the one he is least good at from the beginning. This provides marginal amount of preparation for his research at best.

(Case 2) Macro is most likely exempted for him since he is so good at it that he can pass the entry-exam with reasonably amount of preparation. Then he most likely ends up learning a lot from micro, the one he is least good at from the beginning. This provides marginal amount of preparation for his research at best, again.
column42: My reaction to adding more programming materials in any of the three first-year courses or putting programming course in the first year would always be a "no". Everyone may have difference focus on or preferred methodology for his or her research. Programming is helpful for someone/even most of us does not mean that everyone should take it in the first year as mandatory.
column259: I wrote in the course evaluation form. Presentation should not be mandatory. TA should play a more significant role in teaching!
column274: As noted in course evaluation form, the topics we covered are a bit outdated. We spent way too much time on technical details which have already been fully established in existing research. We aim to build a community yet we started from making a single brick. Meanwhile, a lot of topics that are quite standard in almost every graduate program or more closed to frontier are never touched.
column280:
We were required to do all problem sets together with groups. That said, what we handed in kind of reflected the results of discussion. I see no point when we attend TA session just to listen to presentations of our fellow classmates.
Meanwhile, "opt-in" seems to be more reasonable than current "opt-out" option. Those who ask for a commitment device can freely choose to work together and present. The default, however, would be better if everyone can allocate their time more efficiently.
column294: There is no solution or sample code provided for us to better self-check our progress. Some problem sets are related to material that are not covered in class. The second part of the lecture requires a lot of reading and programming which might be too demanding/not fair for those who will not conduct empirical research in applied micro.
column299: would be better if solutions are provided.
column314: some parts of slides are too vague or abstract
column322: Pietro is very ambitious about this course but the course material is just too much and full of vague BLABLABLA. We tried to talk about everything in this paper or that paper but ended up most of them unclear. The way the second half is taught looks more like a second-year course to me.

column3: We have covered a lot of topics, many of which I didn't study before, so I gained a lot of notions; however, only in some cases I have learned something I feel comfortable to use in my research.
column5: I had already seen a good part of the material; however, for the courses I had some preliminaries the review has been useful, and helped me master the topics. However, for the topics I had weak or zero knowledge before, the first year courses didn't really help me in catching up, and just left me with some learned-by-heart notions that I don't know how to apply in my research. This is unfortunate, as for (e.g) Econometrics, it would be highly important for me to have a deep knowledge of the methods.
column7: This year didn't really help me understand what moves behind the regression, or how to use micro/macro economic tecniques to do applied theory; I struggle in understanding how to read the results when clustering my data, or how to build a model that is a twist or a combination of some warhorses studied in class.
column11: Thanks God we cooperate a lot, and in some cases the help of my colleagues has been more exhaustive and useful than a Professor's class.
column13: Fortunately not, even if I know who are the people better and worse than me; with more competition, I would not have make it.
column17: Cohort atmosphere has saved me from mental breakdowns.
column19: Unfortunately, first year courses only favoured (or almost only) the more mathematical and statistical backgrounds; therefore people with experience in applied research were not really helpful to me.
column21: Workload of Macro and Micro in the first and second semester, and Metrics in the second, has been way higher than for other courses
column23: Waking up at 6,30 is tough; going to exercise sessions EVERY Friday, is tougher.
column25: The Semester is too long, and with almost nine lecture per week, it is not even possible to work with calm; I don't see why we cannot have shorter terms like in many other successful programs.
column27: Impossible to learn through the teaching done in class, useless for the courses.
column29: Many good professors skipped their presentations, and I was just stressed by losing 2 hours of concentration I could use to study.
column42: Less topics, and more "how to do macroeconomics research"!
column51: Even if they help understanding the lecture, somehow they are too long and with too much calculations; as it is not feasible to replicate them in the exam, it would be maybe more useful to have a baseline problem- exam level, and after that a more lenghty one for strenghtening the notions.
column58: Less topics; more "how to tackle this problem in general" sessions; less and more useful TAs on programming
column66: It was good to have him, even if he was less focused on the class material, and more on how to understand his research... but sometimes you need this!
column82: He is maybe the perfect Macro professor
column88: Not always the clearest guy, especially on very lenghty problems, but very friendly and open to explain things as many times as you need
column94: It was difficult to follow her, but she was very professional and friendly
column103: Maybe I would like to know how to use this concepts for Applied Micro research
column107: They were just too difficult sometimes, but certainly they were very thorough
column117: Too long! and it was not clear we had to know some "trivial" things on top of the advanced material covered in class... that turned out to be not so trivial. Bachelor level material is not so easy for a PhD student, hard truth!
column119: Some slides on trivial things, maybe one applied micro paper to study, and... more Hefti!
column139: He didn't look so motivated, and his solutions were often insufficient and sloppy.
column148: I just don't understand what we did, and what we would have needed to do
column152: Useless, too complicated, unsolvable just with class material
column162: Damian has been fair, but I still don't know what I did in the exam
column204: Less, but seriosuly explained, Matlab; a less sloppy teaching of labor; less topics
column220: She looks clear, but she is not: dealing with her problems was very difficult, just using the class material
column228: Very very good! Clear, patient, thorough.
column250: A course covering topics nobody really understands the relevance of; explained really bad and in a sloppy way, gives zero understanding on what Game Theory really is, and how to use it for non-pure theory research. I should understand how to use Game Theory, e.g., to build a political-economy model of conflicts; however, given what I have learned, where do I start from?
column254: Problem sets were really good and useful; too bad the exam was much more difficult and tricky.
column259: Dynamics? Which dynamics? Classes were extremely unuseful, and the interactions concerned only minor issues that didn't help at all understanding the material.
column264: The exam seemed to be written following logics different from "let's evaluate this students' understanding of what I have taught in class". Build to be tricky and difficult to understand without the right intuitions... without any help to develop this intuition.
column266: Change Professor Ewerhart; introduce a week of Game Theory 101 (as it is not in the Precourse, I don't see why we have to know the starting concepts by ourselves); focus on Auctions and applied game theory work.
column274: Professor Ewerhart's behaved in a really unfriendly and unprofessional way, assuming all the doubts and concerns about the class were critiques to his work, doing bad jokes and assuming people were just not interested in his work. On top of being rude and moody, he prepared the class badly for the exam and for pursuing research in microeconomics topics.
column280: A good counterbalance to Professor Ewerhart's flaws, too bad it was not enough.
column290: The first part was interesting, but I didn't have sufficient previous knowledge to understand it, so it turns out to be not so useful to me. The second part maybe is not usual in a PhD first year course, but I think is very helpful.
column294: Provide more exercises on the first part, so to be flexible and able to deal with problems different from the ones in problem sets; even slight modifications, in the exam, made everything impossible. PROVIDE HANDOUT SOLUTIONS!
column299: The handout of Professor Winkelmann should be reduced and enahced with MORE TEXT and maybe examples; the short questions should be exam-style.
column322: Very good, I would just like him to help us understand a bit of the tecniques behind policy evaluation methods, as I guess he could explain them in a good way.

column3: I felt in general that the teaching quality was poor. This is of course subjective, but relative to my masters, I thought the teaching at UZH was not up to snuff. There were of course exceptions, notably Andreas Hefti and Pietro Biroli, but I felt throughout the year that the lack of good teaching made it difficult to digest and understand the material.
column5: There was quite a bit of material I had already seen in my masters, but there was also a lot of material I had not seen. In general the level of the material was higher though.
column7: I would point out that this is very subjective to myself. My research interests are very far away from standard economics, so the first year (anywhere) was never going to be good preparation in general for me. However I can say that I found the econometrics sequence lacking (with the notable exception of Pietro's sequence), which is very important as my work will be empirical. Indeed, I come away from this year thinking Pietro's lectures to be the only part of the first year that will be helpful in the future.
column9: I find it hard to comment on this, as I always knew the first year would be a challenge for me as math is not my forte. I do understand that Zurich wants to build itself into a top program modelled on the best US places. However the difficulty, especially in regards to the exams, felt without purpose in some regards. I think this problem is endemic to economics PhDs and not specific to Zurich, but the first year does feel like an unnecessary baptism of fire. I do not think anyone needs to be challenged this much to learn the relevant material.
column11: This was one of the few positive aspects of the first year, and really helped all of us get through this. I'm worried this will be harmed by the introduction of the UBS scholarship for the person who performs the best, as I think this will foster a competitive atmosphere, at least among the best students.
column17: This was very important to surviving the year. I feel that if the atmosphere had been worse, for example by there being an atmosphere of competition, this year would have been worse by orders of magnitude.
column25: I strongly, strongly disagree with this. The schedule of courses and exams was deeply unpleasant. Having to study over the holidays in the winter was dreadful. I think the reform of having the exams at the end of the term is the right one.
column27: I think this is true for the econometrics sequence. This didn't really happen in micro (though it seems programming is much less useful in micro), and in macro the attempt to make us use matlab seemed well intentioned, but I think very few people bothered. Many of us had no interest in doing macro research, but I would say the matlab exercises seemed not particularly helpful in trying to learn the material.
column29: I very much enjoyed these, though it seemed I was in the minority. I think some students were not very interested in learning about research in fields they are not planning to do work in, but I think the more general problem was that we had so much work to do and so these were given low priority. I think these seminars are extremely useful though, and would advocate making attendance mandatory. I would add that some professors didn't seem to get what they were supposed to do with these and it should be better explained to them that the point is to give a general overview of their work.
column33: Cannot comment, I never met with my junior mentor.
column42: I do not in general have a problem with the material we covered in macro, even though I will not do research in macro. I found the material frequently interesting. I do think the teaching quality was poor however.
column46: At times the problem sets were relevant, at times they were not relevant at all. Frequently they covered material that never showed up on the exams, and I feel that there was a large disconnect between the exams and the problem sets.
column51: I would add that I was one of the few (frequently only) student to ask questions and participate in general in the lectures. I thought throughout the year that class participation was extremely lacking. Perhaps this is purely a function of personality, but I do think there are things the lecturers could do to make people participate more.
column56: The macro exams are what I always did the worst at, and this is probably just my own weakness. The problem in these exams was always time however.
column58: The quality of instruction, the problem sets, and the participation.
column66: Zilibotti clearly has a mastery of the material. However he was very, very fast in covering it and I came away from his lecturers not understanding much of what he taught.
column74: I think Christoph was the best teacher of the macro sequence. He did lecture quite slowly however and sometimes in not a clear way.
column82: The sequence Hemous taught is the part of macro I understood the least. I think he covered the material far too quickly and not at all in a clear way.
column88: Carlo was by far the best TA of macro.
column103: This sequence was probably the hardest of the year for me, as I am weak at this kind of math. Andreas was an excellent lecturer however, though I do think he tried to cover too much. Frequently it felt like he was rushing through material.
column107: The problem sets were very difficult, much more difficult than the exam I would say. I'm not sure if this was useful in preparing ourselves for the exam.
column119: Amount of material covered, speed of the lectures, difficulty of the problem sets.
column127: Hefti was an excellent lecturer. My only criticism would be that he tried to cover too much and the lectures felt rushed at time.
column148: This sequence clearly suffered from the fact that Damian taught it for the very first time. At first, it was far too difficult and unclear. The class did improve over time though as Damian became more familiar with us and our knowledge level.
column152: The problem sets were far, far too difficult and ended up being almost entirely irrelevant to the exam. I think this was again a function of Damian's first time teaching the course.
column164: Organization, communication between the professor and the TA, level of the material.
column172: He clearly suffered from teaching this class for the first time. By the end he was much better though, so I think future years will be better.
column204: Quality of teaching, relevance of problem sets, cohesion of the material.
column250: This class on the whole seemed very narrowly focused and relevant only for those wanting to do micro theory. It was quite difficult to remain interested in the material.
column254: The problem sets did a decent job of helping to learn the material, but the exam ended up being a far departure from them, so they were not very useful.
column264: The exam, especially the second question, was very far away from anything we did in class. It was not a fair exam.
column290: I found Pietro's part to be very relevant and very well taught, and excellent overall. Rainer's part on the other hand was not very relevant, extremely unclear, and I thought poorly taught. I learned a lot from Pietro, but very little from Rainer.
column306: In Rainer's part I would change the quality of instruction, relevance, and material.
column314: I thought Rainer's teaching was poor. I think he was motivated to teach and wanted to teach well, but his teaching was unclear and not well explained. I feel I learned almost nothing from his portion of the class.
column322: Pietro was an excellent instructor, and made a strong effort to foster class participation. I really enjoyed his material with its strong emphasis on applied methods. I especially enjoyed the class debate sessions, from which I think learned very much.

column3: I suggest to diversify the contents of Micro 2.
column7: Econometrics is more research-preparing, but not Micro.
column9: The course contents are mostly challenging, because they normally include a lot of topics. But I think the final exams are not quite challenging.
column21: For the first semester, problem sets of Econometrics are either too difficult or irrelevant, Micro problem sets don't need to be handed in, but Macro problem sets are more detailed and need to be graded. So we spend most time on Macro. In the second semester, the workload is more balanced. Relatively Micro problem sets are difficult, sometimes irrelevant and requires presentation in tutorial classes, so it takes a lot of time. So I would suggest more coordination among the professors, to make the requirements of problem sets more unified.
column23: It feels better to concentrate lectures on a few days and tutorials on other days. For example, lectures from Monday to Wednesday and tutorials on Thursday and Friday.
column27: This part is not given much importance, from my perspective.
column103: There is not much programming technique for this course I guess.
column148: The course did not provide clear programming instructions using R or Stata, although they are necessary for us to understand the contents.
column152: The problem sets are barely relevant, sometimes impossible to solve, even to understand. And please at least provide solutions to the problem sets, or give solutions to the TA such that the TA can help us understand the problems in tutorials.
column162: The exams are quite different from what we learnt from the class and the problem sets. Also the grading policy seems quite unfair. Students studied hard have no difference from those not studied hard.
column164: Course contents should be prepared more properly, with clear notes or slides before hand; Problem sets should be more relevant and basic; topics should be more practical and useful for research.
column250: Much more contents can be included in the syllabus.
column264: The exam should include more small exercises, instead of one or two problems with a clear right or wrong answer.

column7: We learnt a lot of good basic material, but also a lot of material that is quite niche, and unlikely to be useful outside of it's individual field
column15: This worked best when professors made problem sets a group activity
column17: a good cohort atmosphere is helpful for managing the stress of first year, and provides a good support to get through the year successfully
column25: Mid-terms would be nice in order to ensure that material is well-understood throughout the semester
column27: Without knowing the programs before-hand, it was very difficult to complete computing problems, and since they were not applicable for the exams, there was little motivation to work on it. A separate programming course, at least a short one of a week or so, would be far more useful.
column31: Since it was a new program with little information, neither the mentor nor the mentee really knew what their roles were.
column33: Helpful for understanding the progression of the PhD and just getting general advice on the first year
column112: Group requirement for problem sets was nice
column328: Solutions to problem sets for ALL questions

column27: We did not use a lot of programs and never learned to, but I think it is better to do this in second year/over the summer. It was good that we did not have to learn e.g. Matlab for Macro and that most programming exercises were not mandatory. We did use Stata in Metrics and a very big downside was that code was not provided. This would be very useful to improve coding skills and it seems a bit silly to not give solutions only bc the next year's students could copy them.
column29: In general, I think this is a very very useful seminar, but the timing of having it in the first semester of first year is really not ideal. At some point, no one wanted to attend anymore bc it took away a lot of important study and Problemset solving time. Better to have it in second half of first year.
column31: This is great. It'd be nice to be able to give preferences for the mentors, though. But in general, a very good idea and nice to connect to professors.
column33: Did only meet my junior mentor once, but I think in general it is useful to have someone.
column42: Overall, this class seemed to push for quantity of material covered and not necessarily quality. We just covered so many different models without understanding or properly discussing the overarching theme. I think this class would benefit a lot from the professors better organizing who teaches what and what kind of workload this implies for students. The way it was taught last year it seemed that everyone just crammed as much material as they wanted into their part.
column46: The Problemsets were very long and complex, so it was tough to absorb them within one week. But overall good to practice material.
column51: Having to hand in PSets in this class really helped to encourage group work and discussions among peers.
column56: We didn't have enough time during the semester to thoroughly practice all of the models and variations to be able to reproduce (or reproduce variations) of them during the exam. A
column58:
- Choose the material to be covered more wisely and consistently and cover models more in depth (and have fewer models overall)
- Better prepare students for where the course starts in term of math and topics (a lot of stuff was not covered properly in math camp)
- Focus more on understanding things in depth.
column103: The mathcamp for this class really prepared us for what we needed in the course. It was a lot of work, but Hefti encouraged us to give feedback a lot and that really helped to improve the class. Overall, a good class and a motivated teacher. Also, looking at papers on the research frontier was really nice and kept us more motivated.
column107: Solutions (esp. in second half of class/TA) had mistakes and were not very comprehensive. Since TAs messed up in class, this wasn't so great to understand solutions and be able to re-do problemsets
column112: We switched the system for PSets during the semester and group work to solve PSets improved a lot after we randomized presentations.
column117: There were a lot of calculations on the exam (numbers, not proofs) and the PSets and the class mainly focused on proofs, not so much on algebraic solutions. The exam was too long overall.
column119:
- Have more thorough and clearer PSet solutions
- Enforce a system for PSet presentations that makes students work in groups. 
-
column148: This class was a waste of time. We did not really learn anything of substance. Material was not structured, it was not clear what we were learning/ supposed to learn. Classes were not prepared by the professor, instead it seemed to be more of a stream of consciousness involving stats vocabulary.
column152: There were no clear solutions. TA scribbled something on the PSets we handed in. This was mostly unreadable, and also often not correct/ there were no solutions whatsoever to most of the questions in the PSets
column157: I did not learn anything when attending class, so I stopped going. The TA session similarly provided no added value since the TA was too overwhelmed with the material herself.
column162: The exam was not related to material covered in class/Psets and instead asked about basic knowledge in metrics (that we were supposed to have acquired outside of UZH I guess). This was fair given how the class was taught, but overall very frustrating because we didn't really learn anything.
column164:
- Change the teacher
- Maybe move material from second term in Metrics into the first term to not waste so much time  and make sure we have a solid knowledge in stats/metrics
- Have a clear syllabus and make the professor teach the things on there.
column172: It seems a bit unproductive or not very constructive to just suggest switching professors for this course, but I don't even know where to start to list things that he could do to improve.
column178: It wasn't the TA's fault that everything was so unstructured and she didn't have solutions. She was completely overwhelmed with the material and did not manage to convey it well (again, probably not her fault).
column188: Second semester of Macro was still a lot of material but easier to manage. It was good that Matlab exercises were not mandatory.
column250: There are a lot of topics that would have been very important to cover (asymmetric info, moral harzard etc), but the class focused only on very theoretical (and outdated) game theory topics. I do not understand what was the point of this class and why we should know the topics that wer covered. The material covered by the teacher did not seem relevant to a general Econ first year course and I will probably never use it again.
column254: Exam was very different compared to what we did. PSets were ok to cover class material.
column264: Exam was quite unfair. Only two questions that were not clearly stated and hard to understand what they even asked to provide as a solution.
column266:
- Change the teacher. 
- Change the material that should be covered. Spending half a semester on how to prove the existence of a Nash with the index approach seems lie a very bad allocation of time and resources
column274: Professor did not behave adequately. He kept making sexist jokes in class. He also individually threatened students that they would fail the class when they asked questions about the material in class (and it seemed that he could not answer them).
column290: Esp. for Pietro's part, we rushed through the topics and it would have been great to cover more theory (e.g. how to derive the estimators that we were discussing etc). Again, I'd recommend restructuring the topics in the two Econometrics sequences.
column294: There were only solutions provided in the TA session, but there never was enough time to cover everything well and thoroughly. Sometimes solutions provided by the TA on the Pset were wrong/conflicting with TA session/other student's Psets, so it was hard to know which one was a correct solution. Would strongly recommend to provide solutions at least as a hand out.
column304: Exam was too long and especially Winkelmann's part did not really relate very much to concepts covered in class.
column306:
- Spend more time on Pietro's part and understand it better
- Have solution hand outs for PSets.

column25: February break too long, and june exam-preparation too short
column58: less number of different models , more theoretical techniques
column164: Exam didn't reflect course material. Too random. Professor's poor comunication skills
column172: Lectures not clear. Poor organization. Poor comunication. Lack of formal solutions. Changing exam material few days before exam.
column250: Useless to spend the whole semester learning only Game Theory, large opportunity cost for other micro topics.
column264: Exam exercises were unclear. Had to guess what were asked to do. Completely general. Required a lot of memorizing, not much thinking.
column266: Teach other micro topics. Update and modernize content. Avoid old-fashioned methods.
column280: Poor comunication skills. Unefficient methodology of TA sessions.
column294: Should have had proper solutions for a better understanding of the content
column304: First part considerbly more difficult than course material
column322: Many sessions cancelled, changed schedule,... Good intuitive explanationss, lack of deepness.

column7: Not really, though I believe it is quite normal for first year PhD. Would be nice to include recent papers/works as courses' materials, as Hefti did in Micro I.
column21: Macro quite balanced, even between Macro I and II; Micro unbalanced (more intensive Micro I relative to Micro II); Metrics quite unbalanced. Comparing them over the year, all demanding overall and similar in terms of total workload
column23: Better second semester, and in general I would suggest lectures over first half of the week, and TA sessions during the last days (Thursdays and Fridays)
column29: I would say yes, but week workload expected during first year made it hard to attend favorably (maybe move to second year? or allow to choose which ones to attend?)
column42: Given how relevant computing programs are for Macro research, I would suggest to provide an elective course for second year PhD students (with problem sets, similar to the few we had for Macro II to practice), rather than trying to include them in first year classes
column46: I would have preferred to have harder PS and easier exam than the other way around
column188: As said previously, I think there should be no programming in first year courses, and provide electives during second year for those interested (as nobody has anyway the time to learn a computing language to solve PSs during first year)

column7: More applied econometrics would have been useful
column21: Over the year probably yes but during the terms not really
column27: Since it was almost never tested in the exam one ended up not doing to much with computing programs
column42: I liked that we covered so many different models but I was for me not very useful to learn all of them by heart for the exam, a cheatsheet might have been helpful for the exam
column46: The problemsets were good but only one part of the exam was strongly related to the problemsets, the other part I felt was very new and not related at all
column51: Classes starting at 8 are too early
column56: I found one question very confusing, also the structure differed from past exams and it took some time to adjust
column58: Not let it start at 8, let people have a cheatsheet for the exam
column103: I liked the class a lot, it was demanding on a good level, so that you could follow with  reasonable effort after classes
column117: I think the exam was fair in terms of difficulty, but there was definitely not enough time to solve it all if you needed to think for 5 minutes before writing down the solution which I think you should generally be able to do without running out of time in the end then.
column139: For motivation purposes it was a good idea that we had to solve one exercise in front of the class, but sometimes this took very long and was not very comprehensible for the other students if the presented solution was not completely correct or very complicated
column148: It was very long unclear what exactly was the material we were supposed to study, also the lexcture seemed extremely unstructured and incoherent
column152: The problemsets were more or less related to the material in class, however they often required methods to solve them that we did not learn in class and at least I also never learnt before. Also, there were no solutions and the corrections on our handed in solutions were very unclear. So actually for all the exercises we had there I still dont know what the right solution would have been. The TA seemed equally confused as we were and was not really of any help to us, this seemed to be not really her fault though as she told us that the Prof never replied to her emails and did not give out any solutions to her as well.
column157: Class was extremely confusing and seemed to have no structure at all, there was no value for me in attending the class
column162: For most parts of the exam I only used knowledge I already had before this class. However, I was also very glad the exam was this way as if it would have been similar to the problemsets I don't think I could have solved it.
column164: Give structure to the class, make clear which material will be relevant for the exam, give out clear and detailed solutions to the problemsets, make sure problemsets require mostly just methods covered in class or that at least 3/4 of the class know of. Make sure the TA has access to solutions of problemsets in order to be able to help students if they have problems
column178: The TA class was mostly a disaster as the TA did not really know more than we did. But again, I don't think this was due to a lack of motivation on her side, rather lack of information given to her
column202: I thought the exam was very fair in terms of difficulty, maybe a bit more time would have been useful
column204: I did really like this class and would not change much
column250: The material seemed often too specific to be of general usefulness if you are not interested in micro theory. The workload was very fair though
column254: I think the problemsets were mostly fair and doable apart form one or two weird questions during the whole term but in general they were really helpful
column264: The exam was too difficult compared the the problem sets. Without previous knowledge on the topics it was very hard to solve and a large part was very different from problem sets
column266: Mostly the exam, the rest of the class was ok, especially very fair in terms of amount of material covered. Also, I would skip the class presentation of exercises by student, it is apart from motivational purposes really not useful and even confusing
column274: Sometimes response of the Professor to questions in class was questionable, I would rather go ask questions to the TA than the Professor
column280: Aleksei was very motivated and explained everything in a clear way. However, I think it would be more useful if the TA session skipped the presenting solutions by students as this turned out to be more confusing than helpful most of the time.
column290: Especially the second part of the class was useful and I liked that we needed to apply it directly in STATA or R in the exercises.
column294: Problem sets were very helpful and I definitely learnt a lot but sometimes they were too extensive and took too much time which I then lacked for studying for the other two subjects. Also it would have helped if they were a bit more related to class as often they treated material we did not talk about in class and it took a lot of googling to figure it out by oneself. This is only relevant for the second part of the class though, the first was related to material treated in class. For the first part, sometimes the script was a bit confusing and unclear but all in all it was helpful.
column304: Most questions were fair and related to the course, however there was at least one question that treated material we did not talk about at all in class
column306: Shorten problemsets in the second part or treat material asked about in problem sets to some extent in class (or just shorten it, then the googling would be fine as well, but overall it took a lot of time away from the other two subjects in the second half of the term because it took me so long to solve the problemsets.)
column314: The script was helpful but sometimes still a bit unclear and unstructured.
column328: Solutions to exercises might be helpful in a few cases but overall, Janinas corrections on our handed-in homeworks were very clear and useful. There just still remained 4 or 5 questions over the whole term that none of us really did know the right solution to. Those were mostly questions that she only briefly said something about in class but did not write anything down and none of us was fast enough to write it up clearly, so it might be helpful to write everything down and not answer questions only verbally.

column3: I learned a lot for one subject over the others because I knew nothing about it.
column5: It depends on the subject and on the term. For some it is true.
column7: I have the feeling I may use 5-10% of what I've been taught this year.
column11: The offices helped socializing a lot. Good to have them
column17: To me, a sharing and cooperative environment is necessary to perform well. Competition may make studying and understanding more difficult and life miserable.
column19: The first year is already very structured. Hard to get spillovers from students.
column21: Micro and Macro were generally more demanding than metrics. Macro in my opinion way more than any other course. The amount of material is enormeous.
column23: Too many TA sessions were too close to each other, which led us to work almost only on the problem sets during certain days of the week.
column25: To my knowledge, our is the longest lasting first year. I know things will change, because otherwise it's too much time for lectures.
column27: Computing programs were assumed to be known, while tutorials were necessary.
column29: I enjoyed the seminars, especially those where professors shared their experiences and how they work rather than presenting a single paper. It should be made mandatory, otherwise people won't show up.
column31: In my case it was positive, but not 100% useful. There is not that much to discuss at this early stage of the program.
column33: Again, positive experience, but not 100% useful. Maybe a second year student as a junior mentor would have provided more useful tips.
column46: Sometimes I wasn't even able to start the problem set, so definately the very basic models explained in class are not sufficient to solve the exercises.
column51: Participation was compromised by the lectures starting at 8. Hard to show up at that time.
column56: The exam in my opinion was fair.
column58: Reduce the number of topics, change the starting time of the lectures, make students present the problem sets.
column107: More exercises should have been provided to us in order to better prepare for the exam.
column117: The exam was definately too long for me. I couldn't even read some of the questions and barely answered to 60% of them.
column119: Provide more exercises (even unrelated to TA sessions, only for personal exercise), write a fairer exam, make students present the problem set as in Micro II
column152: Problem sets were generally (except maybe the first) extremely difficult and definately not useful for the exam
column157: I stopped attending because I thought lectures were not clear not useful.
column162: The exam was extremely fair as the grading was. I was able to answer mainly thanks to my previous MSc knowledge though.
column164: Improve the teaching, write better problem sets, make students present problem sets.
column172: Keep in mind that my answers come after attending only 5-6 classes.
column178: Once again, my judgement follows from attending 2 TAs.
column188: Professors took for granted MatLab knowledge, big mistake. Once again, the material covered largely exceeds that taught in the other two subjects.
column192: Problem sets were sometimes nowhere related to the material covered in class and I didn't even know how to start. MatLab knowledge sometimes was required, but there is not time to learn how to use MatLab by ourselves.
column202: The exam was long, but fair.
column204: Provide MatLab tutorials, make students present problem sets, provide more real life examples/ data evidence of the models (it's all a bit too abstract sometimes)
column250: The course taught topics never heard and never seen in recent research papers I've ever read. I didn't find it useful.
column254: Considering that the exam was not understandable and very badly structured, I can't say problem sets helped me with it. In general they were enough related to the lectures.
column264: The exam is still a big question mark. Difficult to understand and to solve. Especially if compared with the previous year exam.
column274: The Professor did not make me feel at ease with asking questions because he always thought they were critiques to his quality of teaching and in the end replied in a somewhat rude and provocative way.
column290: The course was very well structured in terms of workload, in my opinion.
column294: All in all, I agree that problem sets were sufficient to answer well at the exam.
column304: The exam was not that easy, but also not unsolvable. Maybe just a bit too long. For Professor Winkelmann's part I would have needed more exercise.
column306: Better lecture notes for Winkelmann's part, more focus on papers/examples for Biroli's part, more exercises for the Winkelmann's part.
column314: Letcure notes can be definately improved.
column322: Sometimes Professor Biroli made confusion in his explanations, which also confused me. Slides were not that exhaustive.
column328: I find in unacceptable that written solutions for the problem sets are not provided. The TA would save time by not having to comment every person's problem set, and we would have a full understanding of the solutions (sometimes the TA was too quick in the explanations and it was hard to take all the necessary notes). For every other subject we had full solutions.

column7: The core sequence covered too broad a range of topics. A lot of the material should have been the focus of second-year topics courses. I cannot help but think that this was a legacy from earlier days when the program did not offer many field courses. In any case, this circumstance made for a pace that was difficult to follow.
column9: I felt challenged mostly because of the fast pace and the very eclectic nature of the core courses.
column13: My answer assumes that "competitive" carries a negative connotation, as in: competitiveness fueled by envy or scarcity of resources. This is certainly not the case in our cohort.
column29: I very much support the idea of the Monday seminars! Unfortunately, not all faculty members seemed to share this sentiment -- absences, re-schedulings and reluctant presentations occurred more than once. New and junior faculty members really seized the opportunity to introduce themselves and their research agendas to us, and I enjoyed those sessions a lot.
column42: Macro I (fall semester) was generally taught at a high level. At times, less breadth of coverage would have been preferable, however. Some of the material, although certainly relevant to many people, may have been pushed to second-year field courses, where it could be dealt with in greater detail. Examples include political economy (where there really should be a specialized set of second-year classes!), but also models of endogenous technological change. With this material outsourced to topics courses, there would have been more time for the core material that I felt we often rushed through, sadly at the expense of achieving a deeper understanding.
column46: We were given one past exam as an example of what to expect. Only after the exam did I learn that there is a comprehensive collection of past exams (with solutions) floating around the department (sourced by Ph.D. students?). This document was available to some but not all students of the cohort. Given the fact that our actual exam sourced most of its questions from those past exams, I feel that this greatly distorted the exam results in January.
column56: With the aid of the unofficial exam archive (covering five or six recent macro exams), the exam was easily solvable -- without it, not so much!
column58:
(1) Stronger focus on core macro material akin to what is covered in top programs (that is, push topics like political economy to field courses). 
(2) Make sure all students enjoy non-discriminatory access to relevant material (past exams were available only unofficially from other Ph.D. cohorts and were not shared with all members of our class).
column280: Micro 2 in its current form feels like a topics course in game theory and mechanism design. I believe that viewed as such, it has the potential to be a really strong course, that is, given that students would then self-select into it, etc. As part of the course sequence, however, its focus is simply too specialized. The TA himself admitted that many of the theorems on existence and uniqueness of Nash equilibria, or theories on learning in games like "fictitious play", are indeed mere sidenotes of the field. While the professor announced at the outset that he wanted to challenges us beyond the concepts he thought we already had a strong command in, I feel that a stronger focus on those would have been beneficial for the vast majority of our cohort.
